2020-01-29T09:17:06.852748+00:00 2020-12-30T17:00:00+00:00 779543.7029004735 false asahimas-flat-glass Asahi Glass Co. Ltd., the world's foremost glass producer was founded by Mr. Toshiya Iwasaki. He was determined to take on the challenge of Japanese domestic flat glass production. In August 1907 his first plant was set in Amagasaki and thus Asahi Glass Co. Ltd. was born.

Asahi Glass Co. Ltd. which was searching for a new overseas production base after Thailand, established Asahimas Flat Glass as a Foreign Investment Company (PMA) with PT Rodamas which was established by trade merchant Mr. Tang Siong Kie. PT Rodamas is a leading Indonesian private business group that has interest in industrial and consumer products. The idea to merge Asahi Glass' technical expertise along with the technology and Rodamas' strong grasp of the local market is a good strategic of partnership that makes Asahimas the glass pioneer in Indonesia.

Asahimas commenced its glass manufacturing in April 1973, from simple clear glass produced using the traditional Fourcault Process. Its product line was quickly diversified to include new and innovative products such as Specialty Glass, Safety Glass, Reflective Glass and Mirror. In 1975 the Company first began construction of its Safety Glass factory and immediately began commercial production using Tempering Process in 1976. In the same year, Asahimas also built the 2nd Furnace for Flat Glass in Jakarta and started its commercial production in 1977. In 1981, Asahimas introduced the Float Glass technology in its new 3rd Furnace in Jakarta, which was the Company's 1st Float Line. In the mean time, Asahimas closed its 2nd Fourcault Process Furnace in the year 1983. In 1985 Asahimas also began construction of its 4th Furnace (2nd Float Line) in Surabaya, which would later began commercial production in 1987. The Company then built its 5th Furnace (3rd Float Line) and 6th Furnace (4th Float Line) in 1990 and 1996, which started its commercial operation in 1993 and 1997 respectively. The former Furnaces are located in Jakarta, while the latter in Surabaya.

1985 was also an essential year for the Safety Glass production, ensuing the introduction of the new Safety Glass laminating process. As a follow-up action to this new technology, Asahimas then began construction of new Laminated Glass production line in 1994, which is the same year with the closing of the 1st Furnace using the Foucault Process. During 1997, Asahimas started the first phase in development of its Safety Glass factory in Bukit Indah Industrial Park, Cikampek, West Java, which later commence its commercial production in 1999.

These days, Asahimas increases an aggregate installed production capacity of 570,000 tons for Flat Glass, 4,500,000 square meters for Safety Glass and 2,400,000 square meters for mirror. This large number of annual capacity ranks Asahimas not only as the largest glass manufacturer in Indonesia but also in Southeast Asia.		 23694 Glass / Ceramics / Concrete https://s3-ap-southeast-1.amazonaws.com/kalibrr-company-assets/logos/C6839DQUA3XE4TZPK9RW-598d5409.png PT Asahimas Flat Glass Tbk true true asahimas-flat-glass Asahi Glass Co. Ltd., the world's foremost glass producer was founded by Mr. Toshiya Iwasaki. He was determined to take on the challenge of Japanese domestic flat glass production. In August 1907 his first plant was set in Amagasaki and thus Asahi Glass Co. Ltd. was born.

Asahi Glass Co. Ltd. which was searching for a new overseas production base after Thailand, established Asahimas Flat Glass as a Foreign Investment Company (PMA) with PT Rodamas which was established by trade merchant Mr. Tang Siong Kie. PT Rodamas is a leading Indonesian private business group that has interest in industrial and consumer products. The idea to merge Asahi Glass' technical expertise along with the technology and Rodamas' strong grasp of the local market is a good strategic of partnership that makes Asahimas the glass pioneer in Indonesia.

Asahimas commenced its glass manufacturing in April 1973, from simple clear glass produced using the traditional Fourcault Process. Its product line was quickly diversified to include new and innovative products such as Specialty Glass, Safety Glass, Reflective Glass and Mirror. In 1975 the Company first began construction of its Safety Glass factory and immediately began commercial production using Tempering Process in 1976. In the same year, Asahimas also built the 2nd Furnace for Flat Glass in Jakarta and started its commercial production in 1977. In the mean time, Asahimas closed its 2nd Fourcault Process Furnace in the year 1983. In 1985 Asahimas also began construction of its 4th Furnace (2nd Float Line) in Surabaya, which would later began commercial production in 1987. The Company then built its 5th Furnace (3rd Float Line) and 6th Furnace (4th Float Line) in 1990 and 1996, which started its commercial operation in 1993 and 1997 respectively. The former Furnaces are located in Jakarta, while the latter in Surabaya.

1985 was also an essential year for the Safety Glass production, ensuing the introduction of the new Safety Glass laminating process. As a follow-up action to this new technology, Asahimas then began construction of new Laminated Glass production line in 1994, which is the same year with the closing of the 1st Furnace using the Foucault Process. During 1997, Asahimas started the first phase in development of its Safety Glass factory in Bukit Indah Industrial Park, Cikampek, West Java, which later commence its commercial production in 1999.

These days, Asahimas increases an aggregate installed production capacity of 570,000 tons for Flat Glass, 4,500,000 square meters for Safety Glass and 2,400,000 square meters for mirror. This large number of annual capacity ranks Asahimas not only as the largest glass manufacturer in Indonesia but also in Southeast Asia.		 false Glass / Ceramics / Concrete false https://s3-ap-southeast-1.amazonaws.com/kalibrr-company-assets/logos/8ZRGZECZSAR8FH2K5R88-598d5409.png https://s3-ap-southeast-1.amazonaws.com/kalibrr-company-assets/logos/BZJAPP2SZYLV7LQMWKMQ-598d540a.png https://s3-ap-southeast-1.amazonaws.com/kalibrr-company-assets/logos/QB4UGGT8QBTB2Z58M32P-598d540a.png https://s3-ap-southeast-1.amazonaws.com/kalibrr-company-assets/logos/C6839DQUA3XE4TZPK9RW-598d5409.png PT Asahimas Flat Glass Tbk http://www.amfg.co.id/ PT Asahimas Flat Glass Tbk 2017-09-05T04:11:50.328643+00:00 <ul>

2020-09-15T03:34:20.184889+00:00 2020-11-12T17:00:00+00:00 false tanihub TaniHub is an Indonesian Agriculture E-commerce solving problems in the supply and distribution chain of agriculture produces. Through the platform and network, TaniHub connect farmers with people in the market to enable farmers selling agriculture products with fair price and sustainable quantity.

Established in late 2015 as an on-demand application to deliver vegetables from farms to houses, in July 2016, TaniHub started to become a Business to Business suppliers for all Agriculture Commodities – Fruit, Vegetable, Poultry, Fishery, Livestock. With the support of TaniXpress, inhouse fresh-products delivery fleet, since October 2017 TaniHub expands to wider online channels, reach more SME’s, Restaurants, Resellers, and end users.

TaniHub wants to be the First Choice in delivering agriculture products from farms to market with affordable price, efficient sourcing, and reliable supply chain. The aim is to bring forward Indonesia by giving market access to as many farmers as possible. By building and growing an integrated agriculture marketplace, the technology will benefit significantly to the growth of agriculture ecosystem in Indonesia.		 25077 E-Commerce Agriculture https://rec-data.kalibrr.com/logos/B48YRWGKBR56JZ5TM23QEQ8L94CBRP96UKQBGJEV-5b4445d0.png TaniHub true true tanihub TaniHub is an Indonesian Agriculture E-commerce solving problems in the supply and distribution chain of agriculture produces. 2020-10-07T08:35:14.737375+00:00 2021-10-06T17:00:00+00:00 false capitalnetid WHO WE ARE

N digital is a new venture within the Large Corporation, focusing on the Personal Financial Management scene for the Indonesian market.

We deploy a future-back approach in defining what game we should play within the industry and making sure we can get ahead of the pack by genuinely believing in the art of the possible.

We have access to a large corporation's resources and networks, but with the velocity of a start-up. Our team is energetic and committed, and we expect the same from every person we hire.


WHAT WE DO

Banking and banking-related products around the world remain practically the same for hundreds of years.

In the Indonesian context, the 200 million-plus Middle Class and Aspiring Middle Class mainly rely on the typical Savings, time deposit, and real estate investment.

All that despite a significant change in the market with the proliferation of e-commerce, OTAs, and ride-sharing where people are already transacting trillions of rupiah every month. On top of that, people are already accessing public services and now, work and learn via online platforms.

The market is ready for a game-changer that will redefine the way people do banking.

We are developing an infrastructure that will allow any customer-facing services, online or offline, to offer banking products and enable the ecosystem to be much more efficient.

HOW?

On one end, we are currently providing other apps, webs, and offline establishments to provide more value to their existing customer more by providing banking products.

On the other end providing access to millions of potential users who previously untouched by the banks.

THE TRUE WINNER?

It is every one of us, by having MORE banking products MORE accessible and EASIER to use to help us achieve whatever financial goals we may have.


﻿
WORK WITH US

Grow Together
Among all the things that get us ahead of the market, we believe people are the only true source of competitive advantage, everything else we can copy or be copied by the competitors.

The only way to truly grow is by growing our people.

The work is our second home
We spend almost half of our time working or thinking about work, whether at the office or home.
We make work feels like home.

Flexibility
Work-life balance is the way of the past. Today's hyperconnected world puts us in constant exposure to family, works, and personal anxieties and desires.

We believe the answer is in work-life integration, where everything goes hand in hand. 		26678 Information Technology / IT https://rec-data.kalibrr.com/www.kalibrr.com/logos/TFC2J8J9AJ25WP8WXPQMWT97JALWSQW2AHUBHK9Z-5f45d7a8.png ndigital (PT. Capital Digital Creative) true true capitalnetid WHO WE ARE

N digital is a new venture within the Large Corporation, focusing on the Personal Financial Management scene for the Indonesian market.

We deploy a future-back approach in defining what game we should play within the industry and making sure we can get ahead of the pack by genuinely believing in the art of the possible.

We have access to a large corporation's resources and networks, but with the velocity of a start-up. Our team is energetic and committed, and we expect the same from every person we hire.


WHAT WE DO

Banking and banking-related products around the world remain practically the same for hundreds of years.

In the Indonesian context, the 200 million-plus Middle Class and Aspiring Middle Class mainly rely on the typical Savings, time deposit, and real estate investment.

All that despite a significant change in the market with the proliferation of e-commerce, OTAs, and ride-sharing where people are already transacting trillions of rupiah every month. On top of that, people are already accessing public services and now, work and learn via online platforms.

The market is ready for a game-changer that will redefine the way people do banking.

We are developing an infrastructure that will allow any customer-facing services, online or offline, to offer banking products and enable the ecosystem to be much more efficient.

HOW?

On one end, we are currently providing other apps, webs, and offline establishments to provide more value to their existing customer more by providing banking products.

On the other end providing access to millions of potential users who previously untouched by the banks.

THE TRUE WINNER?

It is every one of us, by having MORE banking products MORE accessible and EASIER to use to help us achieve whatever financial goals we may have.


﻿
WORK WITH US

Grow Together
Among all the things that get us ahead of the market, we believe people are the only true source of competitive advantage, everything else we can copy or be copied by the competitors.

The only way to truly grow is by growing our people.

The work is our second home
We spend almost half of our time working or thinking about work, whether at the office or home.
We make work feels like home.

Flexibility
Work-life balance is the way of the past. Today's hyperconnected world puts us in constant exposure to family, works, and personal anxieties and desires.

2020-01-30T08:30:37.994426+00:00 2020-12-30T17:00:00+00:00 643970.885004739 false asahimas-flat-glass Asahi Glass Co. Ltd., the world's foremost glass producer was founded by Mr. Toshiya Iwasaki. He was determined to take on the challenge of Japanese domestic flat glass production. In August 1907 his first plant was set in Amagasaki and thus Asahi Glass Co. Ltd. was born.

Asahi Glass Co. Ltd. which was searching for a new overseas production base after Thailand, established Asahimas Flat Glass as a Foreign Investment Company (PMA) with PT Rodamas which was established by trade merchant Mr. Tang Siong Kie. PT Rodamas is a leading Indonesian private business group that has interest in industrial and consumer products. The idea to merge Asahi Glass' technical expertise along with the technology and Rodamas' strong grasp of the local market is a good strategic of partnership that makes Asahimas the glass pioneer in Indonesia.

Asahimas commenced its glass manufacturing in April 1973, from simple clear glass produced using the traditional Fourcault Process. Its product line was quickly diversified to include new and innovative products such as Specialty Glass, Safety Glass, Reflective Glass and Mirror. In 1975 the Company first began construction of its Safety Glass factory and immediately began commercial production using Tempering Process in 1976. In the same year, Asahimas also built the 2nd Furnace for Flat Glass in Jakarta and started its commercial production in 1977. In 1981, Asahimas introduced the Float Glass technology in its new 3rd Furnace in Jakarta, which was the Company's 1st Float Line. In the mean time, Asahimas closed its 2nd Fourcault Process Furnace in the year 1983. In 1985 Asahimas also began construction of its 4th Furnace (2nd Float Line) in Surabaya, which would later began commercial production in 1987. The Company then built its 5th Furnace (3rd Float Line) and 6th Furnace (4th Float Line) in 1990 and 1996, which started its commercial operation in 1993 and 1997 respectively. The former Furnaces are located in Jakarta, while the latter in Surabaya.

1985 was also an essential year for the Safety Glass production, ensuing the introduction of the new Safety Glass laminating process. As a follow-up action to this new technology, Asahimas then began construction of new Laminated Glass production line in 1994, which is the same year with the closing of the 1st Furnace using the Foucault Process. During 1997, Asahimas started the first phase in development of its Safety Glass factory in Bukit Indah Industrial Park, Cikampek, West Java, which later commence its commercial production in 1999.

These days, Asahimas increases an aggregate installed production capacity of 570,000 tons for Flat Glass, 4,500,000 square meters for Safety Glass and 2,400,000 square meters for mirror. This large number of annual capacity ranks Asahimas not only as the largest glass manufacturer in Indonesia but also in Southeast Asia.		 23694 Glass / Ceramics / Concrete https://s3-ap-southeast-1.amazonaws.com/kalibrr-company-assets/logos/C6839DQUA3XE4TZPK9RW-598d5409.png PT Asahimas Flat Glass Tbk true true asahimas-flat-glass Asahi Glass Co. Ltd., the world's foremost glass producer was founded by Mr. Toshiya Iwasaki. He was determined to take on the challenge of Japanese domestic flat glass production. In August 1907 his first plant was set in Amagasaki and thus Asahi Glass Co. Ltd. was born.

Asahi Glass Co. Ltd. which was searching for a new overseas production base after Thailand, established Asahimas Flat Glass as a Foreign Investment Company (PMA) with PT Rodamas which was established by trade merchant Mr. Tang Siong Kie. PT Rodamas is a leading Indonesian private business group that has interest in industrial and consumer products. The idea to merge Asahi Glass' technical expertise along with the technology and Rodamas' strong grasp of the local market is a good strategic of partnership that makes Asahimas the glass pioneer in Indonesia.

Asahimas commenced its glass manufacturing in April 1973, from simple clear glass produced using the traditional Fourcault Process. Its product line was quickly diversified to include new and innovative products such as Specialty Glass, Safety Glass, Reflective Glass and Mirror. In 1975 the Company first began construction of its Safety Glass factory and immediately began commercial production using Tempering Process in 1976. In the same year, Asahimas also built the 2nd Furnace for Flat Glass in Jakarta and started its commercial production in 1977. In 1981, Asahimas introduced the Float Glass technology in its new 3rd Furnace in Jakarta, which was the Company's 1st Float Line. In the mean time, Asahimas closed its 2nd Fourcault Process Furnace in the year 1983. In 1985 Asahimas also began construction of its 4th Furnace (2nd Float Line) in Surabaya, which would later began commercial production in 1987. The Company then built its 5th Furnace (3rd Float Line) and 6th Furnace (4th Float Line) in 1990 and 1996, which started its commercial operation in 1993 and 1997 respectively. The former Furnaces are located in Jakarta, while the latter in Surabaya.

1985 was also an essential year for the Safety Glass production, ensuing the introduction of the new Safety Glass laminating process. As a follow-up action to this new technology, Asahimas then began construction of new Laminated Glass production line in 1994, which is the same year with the closing of the 1st Furnace using the Foucault Process. During 1997, Asahimas started the first phase in development of its Safety Glass factory in Bukit Indah Industrial Park, Cikampek, West Java, which later commence its commercial production in 1999.

These days, Asahimas increases an aggregate installed production capacity of 570,000 tons for Flat Glass, 4,500,000 square meters for Safety Glass and 2,400,000 square meters for mirror. This large number of annual capacity ranks Asahimas not only as the largest glass manufacturer in Indonesia but also in Southeast Asia.		 false Glass / Ceramics / Concrete false https://s3-ap-southeast-1.amazonaws.com/kalibrr-company-assets/logos/8ZRGZECZSAR8FH2K5R88-598d5409.png https://s3-ap-southeast-1.amazonaws.com/kalibrr-company-assets/logos/BZJAPP2SZYLV7LQMWKMQ-598d540a.png https://s3-ap-southeast-1.amazonaws.com/kalibrr-company-assets/logos/QB4UGGT8QBTB2Z58M32P-598d540a.png https://s3-ap-southeast-1.amazonaws.com/kalibrr-company-assets/logos/C6839DQUA3XE4TZPK9RW-598d5409.png PT Asahimas Flat Glass Tbk http://www.amfg.co.id/ PT Asahimas Flat Glass Tbk 2019-07-26T03:54:29.677458+00:00 <ul>

2020-10-02T07:55:08.458672+00:00 2020-12-30T17:00:00+00:00 false pt-bank-mandiri-persero-tbk Bank Mandiri was established on 2 October 1998, as part of the bank restructuring program of the Government of Indonesia. In July 1999, four state-owned banks - Bank Bumi Daya, Bank Dagang Negara, Bank Exim and Bapindo - were amalgamated into Bank Mandiri. The history of these four banks can be traced back to over 140 years, and together they had contributed to the beginning of the Indonesian banking sector.

We are continuously seeking mutually beneficial business opportunities that create synergies, building alliances and strengthening our supporting businesses with and through our subsidiaries, notably Mandiri Sekuritas in investment banking, AXA Mandiri Financial Services in insurance, Bank Syariah Mandiri in Sharia banking, Bank Sinar Harapan Bali in micro banking, and Mandiri Tunas Finance in multi-finance. In 2011, Bank Mandiri acquired Mandiri AXA General Insurance (MAGI), a joint-venture between Bank Mandiri and AXA Societe Anonyme, to strengthen Bank Mandiri's penetration into the general insurance business. With various subsidiaries that support our businesses, we have further strengthened our position as a prominent financial holdings institution in Indonesia.

“Bank Mandiri continues to realize its commitment to human resource development through the company's work culture program, especially in this new normal era. As a result, this consistency encouraged HR Asia to win Bank Mandiri to become one of the Best Companies to Work For in 2020,”

2020-11-05T11:36:10.292936+00:00 2021-01-03T17:00:00+00:00 false dana-indonesia DANA is an open platform digital wallet that bridges financial institutions, merchants and consumers in Indonesia. The platform's purpose is to enable frictionless transaction and to expand financial inclusion especially for the unbanked and underbanked through technology. The technology empowers everyone to transact either for online or offline merchants. Some of the technologies that DANA developed are market pioneers such as: Digital KYC through Face Recognition that enable real-time on-boarding, World Class Risk Management that has the lowest fraud-loss with highest success rate, and the most comprehensive financial instruments acceptance in the country.

DANA was established about a year ago as a new startup. The platform was soft-launched at the end of March 2018. As of July 2018, DANA is the fastest growing startup in Indonesia and among the fastest in the world reaching more than a million new users within a span of less than 4 months. DANA platform has currently on-boarded 7 of the top 10 Banks, Offline Merchants with more than 30 million combined foot-traffic, and Online Merchants with more than 50 million visitors. The company employs more than 200 local talents with a heavy ratio on engineers, half of them recruited within the last 5 months. Ant Financial is an investor of DANA and they share core technology plus know-how exclusively.		 25176 Financial Services https://rec-data.kalibrr.com/logos/YVESCRPMGSS7SGFVYVFSQEVJQ7EX4D7Q3XTRA6WB-5b9b2eac.png DANA Indonesia true true dana-indonesia DANA is an open platform digital wallet that bridges financial institutions, merchants and consumers in Indonesia. The platform's purpose is to enable frictionless transaction and to expand financial inclusion especially for the unbanked and underbanked through technology. The technology empowers everyone to transact either for online or offline merchants. Some of the technologies that DANA developed are market pioneers such as: Digital KYC through Face Recognition that enable real-time on-boarding, World Class Risk Management that has the lowest fraud-loss with highest success rate, and the most comprehensive financial instruments acceptance in the country.

DANA was established about a year ago as a new startup. The platform was soft-launched at the end of March 2018. As of July 2018, DANA is the fastest growing startup in Indonesia and among the fastest in the world reaching more than a million new users within a span of less than 4 months. DANA platform has currently on-boarded 7 of the top 10 Banks, Offline Merchants with more than 30 million combined foot-traffic, and Online Merchants with more than 50 million visitors. The company employs more than 200 local talents with a heavy ratio on engineers, half of them recruited within the last 5 months. <p class="text-justify">We’re looking for a talented <strong>UX Copywriter Intern</strong> to join our rapidly growing Product - User Experience Design team.<br>
<br>
As a UX Copywriter Intern, you need to have a design-thinking, data-driven, and user-centered mindset to write for diverse audiences across all product touchpoints. You’ll be responsible for writing clear, concise, and engaging copy that anticipates and improves user experience.</p>

<p class="text-justify">You’ll also collaborate with other teams to ensure every user gets the right message, at the right time – whether it be a headline, password hint, or error message.<br>
<br>

<li class="text-justify">Strong language &amp; logic skills for writing in both English and Bahasa Indonesia</li>
<li class="text-justify">Have a solid understanding of copywriting techniques is more preferred</li>
<li class="text-justify">Adopt a data-driven and user-centered mindset</li>
<li class="text-justify">Thrive in an agile product cycle environment</li>
<li class="text-justify">A link to your writing portfolio (case studies or any other writing examples)</li>
<li class="text-justify">Experience in related field; experience in website/mobile app is a huge plus</li>

Our main vision is to democratize information. We want to democratize access to accurate, balanced, useful, and positive information and ultimately, to become the voice of Millennials and Gen Z in Indonesia.

IDN Media operates IDN Times, Popbela.com, Popmama.com, Yummy, GGWP.ID, Duniaku.com, IDN Creative, IDN Pictures, IDN Event, IDN Creator Network, IDN Foundation, and IDN Programmatic OOH.


<b>What’s it like working at IDN Media?</b>

<b>Life at IDN Media</b>

The secret ingredient that makes IDN Media a great place to work is the people. You will meet so many Timmy in IDN Media who are equally obsessed and passionate with you in what they are doing. You will be surrounded by extremely smart, friendly, and awesome people who will help you whenever you need them and push you to the next level.

In IDN Media, we do cool things that contribute to the future of Indonesia. We want to bring change and to shape the future of media industry.

<b>Perks and Benefits Working at IDN Media</b>

- Flexible Working Style
- “Wear Anything” dress code policy
- Free lunch and drinks (booze included)
- Free freshly-brewed espresso
- Free Gym at the HQ office
- Performance-driven culture
- Super fun teammates
- Open culture
- More importantly, the opportunity to shape the future of Media Industry in Indonesia

Our perks and benefits are specially designed to keep you happy and healthy (physically, emotionally, and financially). We want to take care of you and make sure that you can focus and enjoy what you are doing here. Ultimately, we want you to become a better person by working at IDN Media.		 25300 Online Publishing https://rec-data.kalibrr.com/www.kalibrr.com/logos/Y4VVZUZVDUASGWT6GLJVH3BBQTLWLHED47SRED2G-5e85b261.png IDN Media true true idn-media IDN Media is the leading media-tech and content platform company focusing on Millennials and Gen Z in Indonesia as the audience. <p>We have now released our powerful content library of more than 80,000 videos into our mobile app in June 2019, and the company has just received seed funding from investors. We are about to embark on a hyper-growth phase to accelerate great learning outcomes for K-12 students in Indonesia.</p>

<p>We are looking for a Website Manager with a minimum of 2 years' experience to join our fast-paced company. This role will help Zenius to achieve business growth by defining, executing, managing, and optimizing a winning website strategy. Together with our tech and content team, you will manage and ensure our website has good quality content and a great user experience.</p>

<p><strong>What You Will be Doing:</strong></p>

<ul>
<li>Work with any related team (content, marketing, tech/product) to translate business objectives into web projects, contents, and plans.</li>
<li>Brainstorm new and creative strategies to increase engagement and web traffic metrics.</li>
<li>Execute test and analyze data of website performance and functionality across browsers, operating systems, and devices.</li>
<li>Track, report and analyze website and app analytics.</li>
<li>Develop and implement a link building strategy.</li>
<li>Stay up to date regarding trends and insight in order to achieve maximum ROI in organic search campaigns.</li>
<li>Identify opportunities for website improvements and quantify impact together with product and technical teams.</li>
</ul>		 550 false 2020-11-09T08:30:12.712341+00:00 Sales and Marketing Graha Aktiva, Jalan Haji R. <ul>
<li>At least 2 years of professional experience as Website Manager or SEO/ASO Manager.</li>
<li>Strong experience in HTML, CSS, Access, MySQL, Javascript, cross-browser &amp; cross-platform compatibility, and firewalls.</li>
<li>Highly skilled in website analytics tools (Google Analytics), SEO/ASO tools (Google Keyword Planner, Ahrefs, SEMrush, App consoles, etc.).</li>
<li>Prior experience with Content Management System WordPress to manage a blog’s SEO.</li>

<li>Self-starter, comfortable working on multiple projects simultaneously.</li>
<li>Has meticulous attention to detail, analytical experience, and creative problem-solving.</li>

2020-11-06T03:05:09.543122+00:00 2020-11-15T17:00:00+00:00 false undp-indonesia UNDP partners with people at all levels of society to help build nations that can withstand crisis, and drive and sustain the kind of growth that improves the quality of life for everyone. On the ground in 177 countries and territories, UNDP offers global perspective and local insight to help empower lives and build resilient nations.” UNDP Indonesia's mission is to be an agent for change in the human and social development of Indonesia. We aim to be a bridge between Indonesia and all donors as
well as a trusted partner to all stakeholders.

We work in four key areas of development: Governance Reforms, Pro-Poor Policy Reforms, Conflict Prevention and Recovery, and Environment Management, with the overarching aim of reducing poverty in Indonesia. Besides the four priority areas, UNDP Indonesia is also engaged in a variety of crosscutting initiatives focused on HIV/AIDS, gender equality, and information and technology for development.”		 21101 Non-Profit / Volunteering https://rec-data.kalibrr.com/www.kalibrr.com/logos/R5WTG425A244XVUSR3EB4FGY5V3U7EYAQQRN5RRA-5ef2def0.png UNDP Indonesia true true undp-indonesia UNDP partners with people at all levels of society to help build nations that can withstand crisis, and drive and sustain the kind of growth that improves the quality of life for everyone. <p>1. Consult with BNPT, The Coordinating Ministry for Human Development and Coordinating Ministry for Political, Legal and Security Affairs, Ministry of Laws and Human Rights and other relevant stakeholders on issues relating to the issuance of the government regulation as mandatory by the Law No. 2 of 2017 and Law No. 5 of 2018</p>

<p>2. Determine methodology, design and work plan of the development of government regulations as mandatory by the Law No. 2 of 2017 and Law No. 5 of 2018; submit inception report for review</p>

<p>3. Identify needs and gaps of the implementation of the laws</p>

<p>4. Identify relevant stakeholders should be engaged for each specific government regulations</p>

<p>5. Map links with local government, NGOs, CSOs, and other entities to have their inputs on the drafting of the operational regulations</p>

<p>6. Conduct several meetings with relevant stakeholder on drafting the operational regulations</p>

<p>7. Submit reports for review, present the findings to the Project and relevant stakeholders through a meeting, make adjustments based on feedback for the final submission of the study</p>

<p>8. Conduct any other activity that promoted the achievement of output, as approved by the Project.</p>

<p> </p>

<p><strong>The expected outputs from the activities are: </strong></p>

<p>1. Government institutions agreed to develop some government regulation as mandatory by Government Regulation in lieu of Law No. 2 of 2017 and Law No. 5 of 2018</p>

<p>2. Draft of some government regulation as mandatory by the Government Regulation in lieu of Law No. 2 of 2017 and Law No. 5 of 2018</p>

<p>3. Facilitate some meeting on the development of government regulation as mandatory by Government Regulation in lieu of Law No. 2 of 2017 and Law No. 5 of 2018</p>

<p>4. Inputs from government counterparts incorporated through FGD and meetings</p>

<p> </p>

<p>Interest candidate has to access procurement notice Ref.: IC/UNDP/PROTECT/071/2020 – Policy Engagement &amp; Facilitator (National Consultant) at the following link: <a href="https://eur03.safelinks.protection.outlook.com/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.id.undp.org%2Fcontent%2Findonesia%2Fen%2Fhome%2Fprocurement.html&amp;data=02%7C01%7Cadmin-intern.id%40undp.org%7Cc0f715a7482c4e5c6c7e08d82e180451%7Cb3e5db5e2944483799f57488ace54319%7C0%7C0%7C637310028256054922&amp;sdata=ofb6uhztUCoTVOZIOILHAQm%2Fg%2BXA6SVUywQgWcR%2FQrI%3D&amp;reserved=0" rel="nofollow">https://www.id.undp.org/content/indonesia/en/home/procurement.html</a> with reference no 72254.</p>

2020-10-05T02:58:45.046585+00:00 2020-12-30T17:00:00+00:00 false finaccel FinAccel is a fun, fast growing company with lofty ambitions. Starting with instant ecommerce financing, we are on a goal to disrupt unsecured lending in Southeast Asia, one of the fastest growing economic regions globally. Our first product, Kredivo, which integrates at merchant checkout, qualifies ecommerce buyers for instant ecommerce purchase financing at rates which are much lower than consumer finance companies. We do this by using breakthrough technology and science to unlock unprecedented insights about credit risk and fraud from multiple data sources: phone, social networks, telco, financial and location data.

FinAccel is founded by an experienced and well rounded team: Akshay Garg (cofounder Komli Media), Umang Rustagi (McKinsey financial services) and Alie Tan (PicStory and Affle). The company is backed by some of the biggest investors in the region: Jungle Ventures, GMO, AlphaJWC and 500 Startups. The company has a flat, egalitarian structure, no politics, no BS; people who are problem solvers and execute fast will thrive here.

FinAccel is not for everyone. People who do well here tend to have a few qualities in common:
- Intelligent
- Intellectually curious
- High ownership over their work
- Strong communicators
- Biased for speed
- Team players
- Excited by an all-in work culture
- Motivated by building innovative products

We provide employees with a work environment which is:
- learning and execution oriented without any politics or excessive managerial overhead,
- where taking initiative is highly valued,
- where making mistakes is encouraged as long as you keep learning from them,
- one of the best compensation structures in the startup world (everyone is a shareholder in the company).

2020-04-15T03:42:06.122815+00:00 2020-12-29T17:00:00+00:00 false pt-bank-mandiri-persero-tbk Bank Mandiri was established on 2 October 1998, as part of the bank restructuring program of the Government of Indonesia. In July 1999, four state-owned banks - Bank Bumi Daya, Bank Dagang Negara, Bank Exim and Bapindo - were amalgamated into Bank Mandiri. The history of these four banks can be traced back to over 140 years, and together they had contributed to the beginning of the Indonesian banking sector.

We are continuously seeking mutually beneficial business opportunities that create synergies, building alliances and strengthening our supporting businesses with and through our subsidiaries, notably Mandiri Sekuritas in investment banking, AXA Mandiri Financial Services in insurance, Bank Syariah Mandiri in Sharia banking, Bank Sinar Harapan Bali in micro banking, and Mandiri Tunas Finance in multi-finance. In 2011, Bank Mandiri acquired Mandiri AXA General Insurance (MAGI), a joint-venture between Bank Mandiri and AXA Societe Anonyme, to strengthen Bank Mandiri's penetration into the general insurance business. With various subsidiaries that support our businesses, we have further strengthened our position as a prominent financial holdings institution in Indonesia.

2020-10-30T01:30:06.033250+00:00 2020-11-12T17:00:00+00:00 false undp-indonesia UNDP partners with people at all levels of society to help build nations that can withstand crisis, and drive and sustain the kind of growth that improves the quality of life for everyone. We aim to be a bridge between Indonesia and all donors as
well as a trusted partner to all stakeholders.

We work in four key areas of development: Governance Reforms, Pro-Poor Policy Reforms, Conflict Prevention and Recovery, and Environment Management, with the overarching aim of reducing poverty in Indonesia. Besides the four priority areas, UNDP Indonesia is also engaged in a variety of crosscutting initiatives focused on HIV/AIDS, gender equality, and information and technology for development.”		 21101 Non-Profit / Volunteering https://rec-data.kalibrr.com/www.kalibrr.com/logos/R5WTG425A244XVUSR3EB4FGY5V3U7EYAQQRN5RRA-5ef2def0.png UNDP Indonesia true true undp-indonesia UNDP partners with people at all levels of society to help build nations that can withstand crisis, and drive and sustain the kind of growth that improves the quality of life for everyone. <p><em><strong>UNDP is the leading United Nations organization fighting to end the injustice of poverty, inequality, and climate change. Working with our broad network of experts and partners in 170 countries, we help nations to build integrated, lasting solutions for people and planet. Learn more at undp.org or follow at @UNDP.</strong></em></p>

<p>UNDP Indonesia's mission is to be an agent for change in the human and social development of Indonesia. We aim to be a bridge between Indonesia and all donors as well as a trusted partner to all stakeholders. We work in four key areas of development: Governance Reforms, Pro-Poor Policy Reforms, Conflict Prevention and Recovery, and Environment Management, with the overarching aim of reducing poverty in Indonesia. Besides the four priority areas, UNDP Indonesia is also engaged in a variety of crosscutting initiatives focused on HIV/AIDS, gender equality, and information and technology for development.”</p>

<p> </p>

<p>UNDP Office has organised internship programme to provide a framework by which students from diverse academic backgrounds may be assigned to UNDP offices, where their educational experience can be enhanced through practical work assignments as well providing an opportunity to make substantive contributions to an office’s work. The current internship will provide opportunity for student or student who recently graduated from university to learn some aspects of the Administrative Unit in UNDP.</p>

<p> </p>

<p><strong>Tasks</strong></p>

<p>Under the direct supervision of<em> <strong>Partnership Development Specialist </strong></em>the Intern will undertake the following tasks<em>:</em></p>

<p><strong>1. Effective support for coordination, partnerships building, compliance with donor requirement, focusing on the following tasks:</strong></p>

<ul>
<li>Supporting supervisors in preparation of quarter and period report on progress made in establishing and operationalizing philanthropy platform and achieving target as outlined in work plan</li>
<li>Provision of support for period meetings with various stakeholders</li>
<li>Updating database of partners</li>
<li>Supporting coordination with programme unit, communication unit to strengthen result, deepen stakeholder’s knowledge and buy -in and to support resource mobilization activities.</li>
<li>Support the organisation of high-level missions, events, launches and press conferences in coordination with communication team.</li>
</ul>

<p><strong>2. Assist in managing external resources and maintaining relations with external partners, focusing on the following tasks: </strong></p>

<ul>
<li>Supporting supervisors in drafting concept notes and project proposals are in order as per discussions and agreements with donors.</li>
<li>Supporting supervisors in negotiation, drafting and revision of agreements with donors.</li>
</ul>

<p><strong>3. Supporting communications aspect of the work, focusing on the following tasks:</strong></p>

<ul>
<li>Supporting supervisor in coordination with Country Office Communication team in increasing profile and support positive positioning vis-à-vis donor partners</li>
<li>Assist with development of English language communications materials and best practices</li>
<li>Organization and implementation of public events such as commemoration of internationally marked days. Philanthropy platform event, etc</li>
<li>Ensuring documentation of best practice lesson learn and actively contribute to knowledge network and communities of practices</li>
</ul>

<p><strong>Outputs</strong></p>

<p><strong>Results/Expected Outputs:</strong></p>

<ul>
<li><strong>Timely quarter and period report on progress as outlined in work plan </strong></li>
<li><strong>Effective support for period meetings with various stakeholders </strong></li>
<li><strong>Updated database of partners </strong></li>
<li><strong>Effective support for coordination with programme unit, communication unit to strengthen result, deepen stakeholders knowledge and buy -in and to support resource mobilization activities. </strong></li>
<li><strong>Effective support for high-level missions, events, launches and press conferences in coordination with communication team. </strong></li>
<li><strong>Timely preparation draft concept notes and project proposals </strong></li>
<li><strong>Effective support for negotiation, drafting and revision of agreements with donors. </strong></li>
<li><strong>Effective coordination with Country Office Communication team in increasing profile and support positive positioning vis-à-vis donor partners</strong></li>
<li><strong>Provision of support for draft communications materials and best practices </strong></li>
<li><strong>Effective support for public events such as commemoration of internationally marked days. Philanthropy platform event, etc </strong></li>
<li><strong>Proper documentation of best practice lesson learns </strong></li>
<li><strong>Age, Gender and Diversity (AGD) perspective is systematically applied, integrated and documented in all activities throughout the assignment;</strong></li>
<li><strong>A final statement of achievements towards volunteerism for development during the assignment, such as reporting on the number of volunteers mobilized, activities participated in and capacities developed.</strong></li>
</ul>		 550 false 2020-11-09T08:48:29.335230+00:00 Administration and Coordination Menara Thamrin, Jl. M.H. Thamrin Kav. 3, Jl. M.H. Thamrin Kav. 3, Kebon Sirih, Central Jakarta Central Jakarta Indonesia Jakarta 128925 false false INTERNSHIP FOR PARTNERSHIP UNIT 1 1 <p><strong>Qualifications </strong></p>

<p><strong>The following minimum qualifications are required:</strong></p>

<ul>
<li>Enrolment in bachelor degree level <strong>OR</strong> Bachelor degree graduate (internship period within one year of graduation) <strong>OR</strong> Enrolment in a graduate-level degree programme in relevant studies Economics, Business Management, Social Sciences, International Relations, Political Sciences or other relevant field;</li>
<li>Demonstrated interest and/or experience (up to 2 years) in in partnerships building, proposal development and relationship management. Some experience in design, monitoring and evaluation of development projects would be preferable.</li>
<li>Experience in the usage of computers and office software packages, experience in handling of web-based management systems and advanced programmes for data analysis</li>
<li>Research skill is desirable, powerpoint and digital production are a plus.</li>
<li>Motivated to contribute towards peace and development and to serve others;</li>
<li>Good interpersonal, networking and communication skills;</li>
<li>Willingness to contribute and work as part of a team;</li>
<li>Flexible and open to learning and new experiences;</li>
<li>Fluency in spoken and written English is required, and knowledge of other language is an asset;</li>
<li>Computer literate in standard software applications;</li>
<li>Demonstrated keen interest in the work of the UN, and of UNDP in particular, and have a personal commitment to UNDP's Statement of Purpose and to the ideals of the UN Charter;</li>
<li>Demonstrated the ability to successfully interact with individuals of different cultural backgrounds and beliefs, which include willingness to try and understand and be tolerant of differing opinions and views</li>
<li>Good communication skills; speaking, writing and editing skills in English</li>
<li>Demonstrable skills in analytical thinking, report writing, communication, and research.</li>
<li>An interest in global mobility; adaptability to varied physical and other environments; a desire to work with and gain the confidence and respect of people with different language, national and cultural backgrounds.</li>
</ul>

<p> </p>

<p><strong><u>Financially Issues</u></strong></p>

<p><em><strong>Interns are only eligible for a monthly stipend for UNDP</strong></em></p>

<p>All costs connected with an intern’s participation in the Programme must be borne by:</p>

<ol style="list-style-type: lower-alpha;">
<li>The nominating institution, related institution or government, which may provide the required financial assistance to its students;</li>
<li>The student, who will have to obtain financing for subsistence and make his/her own arrangements for travel (including to and from the office), visas, accommodation, etc.</li>
</ol>		 13.72549019607843 true internship-for-partnership-unit Full time public 100 32 0 2014-07-03T21:01:25.291298+00:00 420 85 false 10 2 43 0 2014-07-23T04:19:42.008585+00:00 1198 720 95 false 17 1
2020-01-02T04:16:35.207225+00:00 2020-12-30T17:00:00+00:00 false pt-bank-mandiri-persero-tbk Bank Mandiri was established on 2 October 1998, as part of the bank restructuring program of the Government of Indonesia. In July 1999, four state-owned banks - Bank Bumi Daya, Bank Dagang Negara, Bank Exim and Bapindo - were amalgamated into Bank Mandiri. The history of these four banks can be traced back to over 140 years, and together they had contributed to the beginning of the Indonesian banking sector.

We are continuously seeking mutually beneficial business opportunities that create synergies, building alliances and strengthening our supporting businesses with and through our subsidiaries, notably Mandiri Sekuritas in investment banking, AXA Mandiri Financial Services in insurance, Bank Syariah Mandiri in Sharia banking, Bank Sinar Harapan Bali in micro banking, and Mandiri Tunas Finance in multi-finance. In 2011, Bank Mandiri acquired Mandiri AXA General Insurance (MAGI), a joint-venture between Bank Mandiri and AXA Societe Anonyme, to strengthen Bank Mandiri's penetration into the general insurance business. With various subsidiaries that support our businesses, we have further strengthened our position as a prominent financial holdings institution in Indonesia.

“Bank Mandiri continues to realize its commitment to human resource development through the company's work culture program, especially in this new normal era. As a result, this consistency encouraged HR Asia to win Bank Mandiri to become one of the Best Companies to Work For in 2020,”

2020-10-29T03:59:21.561774+00:00 2020-11-11T17:00:00+00:00 false undp-indonesia UNDP partners with people at all levels of society to help build nations that can withstand crisis, and drive and sustain the kind of growth that improves the quality of life for everyone. On the ground in 177 countries and territories, UNDP offers global perspective and local insight to help empower lives and build resilient nations.” UNDP Indonesia's mission is to be an agent for change in the human and social development of Indonesia. We aim to be a bridge between Indonesia and all donors as
well as a trusted partner to all stakeholders.

We work in four key areas of development: Governance Reforms, Pro-Poor Policy Reforms, Conflict Prevention and Recovery, and Environment Management, with the overarching aim of reducing poverty in Indonesia. Besides the four priority areas, UNDP Indonesia is also engaged in a variety of crosscutting initiatives focused on HIV/AIDS, gender equality, and information and technology for development.”		 21101 Non-Profit / Volunteering https://rec-data.kalibrr.com/www.kalibrr.com/logos/R5WTG425A244XVUSR3EB4FGY5V3U7EYAQQRN5RRA-5ef2def0.png UNDP Indonesia true true undp-indonesia UNDP partners with people at all levels of society to help build nations that can withstand crisis, and drive and sustain the kind of growth that improves the quality of life for everyone. <li><strong> Project Description</strong></li>
</ul>

<p>This is the Terms of Reference (ToR) for -the Midterm Review (MTR) of the full-sized UNDP-supported<br>
GEF-financed project titled Combatting illegal and unsustainable trade in endangered species in Indonesia<br>
(PIMS-5391) implemented through the Directorate General of Law Enforcement on Environment and<br>
Forestry Ministry of Environment and Forestry which is to be undertaken in 7 year. The project started in<br>
November 2017 and is in its third year of implementation. This ToR sets out the expectations for this MTR.<br>
The MTR process must follow the guidance outlined in the document Guidance For Conducting Midterm<br>
Reviews of UNDP-Supported, GEF-Financed Projects<br>
(http://web.undp.org/evaluation/documents/guidance/GEF/midterm/<br>
Guidance_Midterm%20Review%20_EN_2014.pdf).<br>
The project seeks to address the devastating impact of unsustainable and illegal wildlife trade (IWT) on wildlife<br>
populations in Indonesia and SE Asia. The value of the illegal trade in Indonesia alone is estimated at up to<br>
US$ 1 billion per year. Factoring in the unsustainable legal trade, the value rockets, representing an enormous<br>
economic, environmental, and social loss. This trade has already caused the decline and local extinction of many<br>
species across SE Asia. Much of the trade is highly organized, benefits a relatively small criminal fraternity,<br>
whilst depriving developing economies of billions of dollars in lost revenues and development opportunities.<br>
Within SE Asia, a significant amount of this trade starts from Indonesia, one of the world’s top 10 ‘megadiverse’<br>
countries and the largest supplier of wildlife products in Asia, both ‘legal’ and illegal. The IWT and associated<br>
bushmeat trade are an immediate threat to the existence of key endangered species such as the Sumatran and Javan Rhinoceros, Sumatran Tiger, Asian Elephant and Sunda Pangolin amongst a wide range of less prominent<br>
species. Indonesia is also becoming an important transit point for IWT from Africa to East Asia, such as African<br>
Ivory. The consequence of the unsustainable trade is a massive<br>
threat to globally important wildlife.<br>
The project aims to remove the barriers to accomplishing the long term solution to this challenge, namely to<br>
conserve key wildlife species in Indonesia, by ensuring that the legal wildlife trade is ecologically and<br>
economically sustainable, while reducing the scale and impact of illegal wildlife trafficking, both from Indonesia<br>
and in transit through the country.<br>
The Project Objective is to reduce the volume of unsustainable wildlife trade and the rate of loss of globally<br>
significant biodiversity in Indonesia and East and South-East Asia. The four outcomes of the project are:<br>
Outcome 1: Strengthened national policy, legal and institutional framework for regulating legal commercial<br>
wildlife trade and combating illegal wildlife trade.<br>
Outcome 2: Strengthened institutional capacity for regulatory coordination, implementation and enforcement<br>
at the national and international levels.<br>
Outcome 3: Improved enforcement strategy demonstrated and scaled up at key trade ports and connected<br>
subnational regions with key ecosystems.<br>
Outcome 4: Implementation and upscaling/replication of project approaches at national and international<br>
levels is supported by effective knowledge management and gender mainstreaming.<br>
This project is part of the GEF Programmatic Approach to Prevent the Extinction of Known Threatened<br>
Species, and falls under the GEF Programme Global Partnership on Wildlife Conservation and Crime<br>
Prevention For Sustainable Development which is led by the World Bank.<br>
The total allocated resources for this project is US $ USD 6,988,853. In addition, in-kind Parallel Funding is<br>
US $ 51,937,595 from the Government of Indonesia and NGO partners. Directorate General of Law<br>
Enforcement on Environment and Forestry under the Ministry of Environment and Forestry is the<br>
Implementing Partner for the project.<br>
xxx<br>
As of 30 August 2020, there were 172,053 confirmed cases of Covid-19 in Indonesia, of which 7,343 were<br>
fatalities and 124,185 persons recovered. Covid-19 has spread in 34 provinces and 487 regencies/cities across<br>
Indonesia. Some regions implemented large social restrictions to prevent Covid-19 pandemics. Covid-19<br>
pandemics have affected the implementation of the project. Based on the assessment, some works can continue<br>
on-schedule, while some are deferred and likely to delay and some may need readjustment to adapt to the new<br>
normal.</p>

<ul>
<li><strong>MTR Purpose</strong> The MTR will assess progress towards the achievement of the project objectives and outcomes as specified inthe Project Document, and assess early signs of project success or failure with the goal of identifying the necessary changes to be made in order to set the project on-track to achieve its intended results. The MTR will also review the project’s strategy and its risks to sustainability.The MTR will also look at any project interventions that have contributed directly or indirectly to government’s effort of COVID-19 recovery both at the national level and project sites.</li>
</ul>

<p> </p>

<ul>
<li><strong>Duties and Responsibilities</strong></li>
</ul>

<p>Detailed tasks of a national consultant as follows:<br>
1. Provide input into the Inception Report to be drafted by the IC (International Consultant). In<br>
particular, the NC should:<br>
a. Consult with the PMU to develop the draft project site visit itinerary, taking into consideration<br>
guidelines on-site visits and stakeholder consultations provided by the International<br>
Consultant/Team Leader (IC)<br>
b. Prepare an evaluation question matrix to be used in conjunction with that prepared by the IC<br>
and focused specifically on those consultations that will take place during field visits.<br>
2. Maintain the up-to-date actual itinerary of the Evaluation Team (ET) for all in-country meetings<br>
conducted<br>
3. Maintain an up-to-date comprehensive list of persons met by the ET (all meetings, including those<br>
held by zoom, skype, or otherwise virtually)<br>
4. Prepare a list of all products/outputs (technical reports, land use or management plans, curricula,<br>
etc.) produced with project financial support<br>
5. Review products as indicated by the IC &amp; provide product assessment using the format provided by<br>
the IC<br>
6. Prepare a list of all training conducted with project financial support<br>
7. At outset of assignment, brief IC on updated institutional/policy/legislative frameworks relevant to<br>
the project and on key relevant in-country initiatives (national and state government<br>
programs/campaigns), NGO activities, and donor-supported projects)<br>
8. Undertake in-country consultations<br>
9. Summarize each consultation undertaken ensuring that important data is recorded that allows for<br>
detailed, evidence-based observations and conclusions to be drawn.<br>
10. Engage with IC in review and analysis of important information gained during the day’s meetings<br>
during regularly scheduled twice weekly zoom or skype calls<br>
11. Engage with IC in the analysis of evaluation findings<br>
12. Participate as requested by the IC in the preliminary presentation of evaluation findings<br>
13. Take photos of site visits for inclusion in the evaluation report<br>
14. Fill in information gaps as needed following the drafting of the Evaluation report by IC</p>

<p> </p>

<p> </p>		 650 false 2020-11-09T08:48:29.335230+00:00 Management and Consultancy Menara Thamrin, Jl. M.H. Thamrin Kav. 3, Jl. M.H. PT BFI Finance Indonesia Tbk was founded in 1982. It is one of the oldest and the most diversified multi finance companies in Indonesia as well as the first multi finance company to be listed on Indonesia Stock Exchange with ticker code BFIN. Currently BFI Finance had over 300 branch and 9000 employee across the nation.

In 2017, PT BFI Finance Indonesia Tbk build a subsidiary called PT Finansial Integrasi Teknologi (FIT). We believe that technology can facilitate more financial access to Indonesian people. <b>Life at IDN Media</b>

Our portfolio includes personal care item such as soap, lotion and fragrances and food item such as cooking oil and margarine. If you are excited by the thought of a dynamic job which touches the everyday lives and need of millions across Indonesia, we are speaking to you.

To be one of the TOP 5 leading Fast Moving Consumer Goods company in Indonesia & simultaneously becoming a blue chip listed company

2020-11-03T12:06:54.723646+00:00 2021-01-01T17:00:00+00:00 false pt-payfazz-teknologi-nusantara PAYFAZZ (PT Payfazz Teknologi Nusantara) is a financial technology startup from Indonesia that was established in 2016. PAYFAZZ creates a distributed network of bank agents in Indonesia, who performs financial transactions on behalf of unbanked and underbanked customers.

PAYFAZZ is on a mission to empower SMEs and the rural population with technology to build Indonesia’s digital economy, and vision is to become a world class technology company and the best digital integration platform for Indonesia's digital economy. We can accomplish our mission by minding our STEP. Our STEP values helps all employees to Start Small, to Take a Lead, to be Eager to Grow, and to become Pro-Customer. By that PAYFAZZ will create an ecosystem revolving around solving the needs of our customers — it will be better than any competing ecosystem or platform.

2020-10-20T07:26:44.559166+00:00 2020-12-30T17:00:00+00:00 false pt-asuransi-astra-buana Asuransi Astra has been serving customers for more than half a century, precisely since September 12, 1956. The company, known for its Garda Oto motor vehicle insurance products, serves customers through a network of services spread across 28 branch offices, as well as service units and Garda Centers that continue developing. In addition to motor vehicle insurance, other products from Asuransi Astra are Garda Medika health insurance, mining industry insurance, agribusiness industry insurance, shop insurance, gas station insurance, sharia insurance, and others.

Since 2015, Asuransi Astra has developed its products and services digitally and introduced Garda Mobile as a collection of mobile applications intended for retail, commercial and general customers. The four Garda Mobile applications namely Otocare, Medcare, HR-access, and CR-access are consistently updated through various innovations aimed at customer convenience and comfort. The latest innovation developed in the Garda Mobile Otocare with the presence of GarXia, the first insurance purchase chatbot in Indonesia that can also help customers in reporting claims and the Garda Mall feature that allows users to shop for a variety of automotive needs, Astra Financial financial products, also to buying and selling cars. Asuransi Astra also has four digital products namely Garda Me, Garda Edu, Garda Home, and Garda Trip which can be purchased easily and quickly through the gardaoto.com site.

Asuransi Astra performance has also been recognized with various awards that have been received, including: Platinum Indonesia Best Brand Award (2002-2019), Top Brand Award (2007-2019), Service Quality Award (2007-2018), Corporate Image Award ( 2007-2019), Indonesian Customer Satisfaction Award (2001-2017), Indonesia Original Brand Award (2017-2019), General Insurance with very good financial performance in the Infobank Insurance Award (2008-2016, 2019), Excellent Service Experience Award (2013 -2020), Contact Center Service Excellence Award (2013-2020), Social Media Award (2012, 2016), Indonesia Sharia Finance Award (2017), Insurance Award (2017-2018), Insurance Consumer Choice Award (2017-2018), Asian Brands (2018), Marketing Award (2018), Indonesia Digital Innovation Award (2018), Markeeter of the Year (2018-2019), Infobrand Mobile Application Choice (2018), Marketeers Editor Choice Award (2018-2019), Indonesia Insurance Innovation Award (2019), Indonesia Digital Popular Brand Award (20 19), and others.

2020-11-09T09:16:37.055104+00:00 2021-01-07T17:00:00+00:00 false pt-payfazz-teknologi-nusantara PAYFAZZ (PT Payfazz Teknologi Nusantara) is a financial technology startup from Indonesia that was established in 2016. PAYFAZZ creates a distributed network of bank agents in Indonesia, who performs financial transactions on behalf of unbanked and underbanked customers.

PAYFAZZ is on a mission to empower SMEs and the rural population with technology to build Indonesia’s digital economy, and vision is to become a world class technology company and the best digital integration platform for Indonesia's digital economy. We can accomplish our mission by minding our STEP. Our STEP values helps all employees to Start Small, to Take a Lead, to be Eager to Grow, and to become Pro-Customer. By that PAYFAZZ will create an ecosystem revolving around solving the needs of our customers — it will be better than any competing ecosystem or platform.

Our Founders, who were also crowned by Forbes 30 Under 30, never lost sight of their Mission and Vision to help #FAZZFORWARDINDONESIA, and that resulted in PAYFAZZ being the first Indonesian company to receive seeding money from Y Combinator. Three years later, PAYFAZZ was included in the top 100 Y Combinator companies of all time, based on valuation. PAYFAZZ was also named as the fastest moving businesses of the SME sector, and being the Best Company to work for in Asia 2019.

PAYFAZZ has grown immensely, because our Founders took a big STEP to help #FAZZFORWARDINDONESIA.
